Award.AwardTitle: Moisture Budget and Air-Sea Interaction Associated with Atmospheric Rivers in the Northeast Pacific: Observations and Climate Model Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to evaluate the structure and mechanism of atmospheric rivers (ARs) in the northeast Pacific and their impacts on U.S. weather simulated by global climate models, and understand the physical processes responsible for the systematic errors in the simulations. An analysis of satellite observations and reanalysis products including computation of composite sea surface temperature, air-sea fluxes and moisture budget associated with ARs will be undertaken. An examination of the impact of low frequency variability such as El Nino Southern Oscillation and Madden Julian Oscillation on ARs will also be investigated. An intercomparison of global climate model simulation, including the evaluation of AR simulations and the impact of the double Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) problem on precipitation along the U.S. West Coast through AR activity will be performed. The research will include conducting atmospheric coupled model experiments with prescribed sea surface temperatures (SST), which include the erroneous SST field associated with the double (ITCZ) problem. Finally upper ocean processes associated with ARs that could influence SST and air-sea fluxes of moisture using ocean coupled modeling experiments will be examined.

This research will shed insights into ARs that are an important mode of providing precipitation to the western US. Enhanced understanding of ARs thus has important societal impacts and benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brief Summary of the outcomes

Atmospheric rivers (ARs) are narrow corridors or filaments of concentrated moisture in the atmosphere, and occasionally cause heavy rainfall and flooding in the west coasts of many mid-latitude continents (e.g. western N. America) when they make landfall. The primary goal of this project is to understand the role of air-sea interaction and extra-tropical cyclones in the formation and maintenance of ARs.  We have analyzed atmospheric and ocean reanalysis products as well as other available data including those collected during the recent field campaign, CalWater 2015, to achieve the goal described above. The major outcomes from the analyses are briefly descried in the following:

Air-sea interaction associated with ARs

 Because of an important role of ARs in the global water cycle as well as societal impacts caused by extreme weather events in many coastal areas, atmospheric processes associated with ARs have been studied intensively in the last few decades. However, associated ocean variability and air-sea fluxes have received little attention because of the lack of high resolution ocean data until recently. In this study, we demonstrate that typical ARs can generate strong upper ocean response and substantial air-sea fluxes using the high-resolution (1/12°) ocean reanalysis. 

AR events observed during the CalWater 2015 field campaign generate prominent sea level rise along the west coast of North America (Fig. 1, Fig. 2). In association with the sea level rise near the coast, a strong northward jet with the maximum velocity of about 1 m/s is generated. When the AR makes landfall, large-scale on-shore currents that hit the coast, generating strong narrow northward jets along the west coast of North America (Fig. 3). In the open ocean, the AR generates prominent changes of mixed layer depth especially south of 30°N due to the strong surface winds and air-sea heat fluxes. The prominent cooling of SST is observed only in the vicinity of AR upstream areas primarily due to the large latent heat flux. Using a long-term AR dataset, composite structure and variations of upper ocean and air-sea fluxes are presented, which are consistent with those found in the events during CalWater 2015 (Fig. 4).

ARs and tropical cyclones

ARs are often associated with a strong cyclone in the extratropics, being considered as the water-rich part of the warm conveyor belt of an extratropical cyclone (EC). However, the relationship between ARs and ECs has not been well investigated. Using a newly available global AR dataset, we demonstrated that in addition to the cyclone, the presence of an anticyclone equatorward and eastward of the AR centroid plays an essential role in the formation of AR through generating narrow areas of strong pressure gradient and winds between the cyclone and anticyclone (Fig. 5). It is found that the strength of ARs is better correlated with the pressure gradient between the cyclone and anticyclone than with the cyclone intensity (Fig. 6). 

 

Intellectual merit

The outcomes of the project provided insights into key processes in the generation and development of ARs. In particular, the important role of anti-cyclone in the AR-EC system, which has not been emphasized in previous studies, is clearly demonstrated based on the composite analysis using a long-term global AR dataset. In addition, we found that ARs can generate strong upper ocean response and substantial air-sea fluxes. Such surface fluxes and ocean variability produced by ARs could then in turn feedback on the ARs through SST changes. Thus our results have contributed to improving our understanding of the dynamics of ARs and their role in the coupled ocean-atmosphere system in the tropics and subtropics.

 

Broader impacts

 ARs play an important role in the incidence of extreme precipitation events along the west coast of North America. Yet the simulation and prediction of ARs variability in global climate models is one of the major challenges for their further improvement. This project has improved our understanding of processes that control the evolution of ARs. Accordingly, our results will help improve climate model simulation, and thus will benefit society (especially in US) by providing more reliable weather and climate prediction. Also, the project has promoted interdisciplinary training through funding post-docs and students. A significant portion of work has been carried out by students and post-docs under supervision of PIs and their collaborators, and thus the project has contributed to the enhancement of education. Furthermore, we shared our preliminary results of ocean variability associated with ARs for the CalWater 2015 planning meeting, which provided useful information for designing the ocean measurements.
